title: 105_s2347
content: The Act is titled the "Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act" and aims to expand prevention efforts for methamphetamine abuse. The Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act aims to prevent methamphetamine abuse by providing grants for school-based and community-based prevention programs. The Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act provides funding for evidence-based prevention programs targeting districts with high rates of methamphetamine abuse, focusing on populations at risk. The Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act funds prevention programs targeting high-risk populations, community-based initiatives, local government assistance, and training for law enforcement on methamphetamine abuse signs and treatment options. The Director shall prioritize funding for planning, administration, educational activities, monitoring, evaluation, reporting, dissemination, and targeted pilot programs to prevent methamphetamine abuse and addiction. The Director prioritizes funding for prevention programs in areas with high methamphetamine abuse rates. $500,000 annually is allocated for analyses and evaluations of effective prevention strategies. The Director allocates $20,000,000 for prevention programs and submits annual reports on program evaluations to specific committees for review and authorization of appropriations. SEC. 3. EXPANDING CRIMINAL PENALTIES AND LAW ENFORCEMENT FUNDING. The United States Sentencing Commission will create or amend federal sentencing guidelines for offenses related to manufacturing methamphetamine in violation of certain acts. The United States Sentencing Commission will increase the base offense level for offenses related to manufacturing methamphetamine in violation of certain acts by at least 3 levels above the current level. The United States Sentencing Commission will increase the base offense level for offenses related to manufacturing methamphetamine by at least 3 levels above the current level. If the offense poses a substantial risk of danger to others, the base offense level may be increased by 6 levels above the current level. The United States Sentencing Commission will increase the base offense level for offenses related to manufacturing methamphetamine by at least 3 levels above the current level, with a potential increase of 6 levels for offenses posing a substantial risk of danger to others. The Sentencing Commission is granted emergency authority to promulgate guidelines or amendments promptly after the enactment of this Act. The Act of 1987 is extended, with amendments applying to offenses after 60 days of enactment. Increased funding is authorized for combating methamphetamine trafficking in designated areas. SEC. 4. TREATMENT OF METHAMPHETAMINE ABUSE. Section 507 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to allow grants for expanding treatment activities for methamphetamine abuse and addiction. The Director may make grants to public and non-profit entities for planning, establishing, or administering methamphetamine treatment programs. Treatment programs and activities funded under this subsection include evidence-based programs to help individuals quit methamphetamine use, training for health professionals on recognizing and treating methamphetamine abuse and addiction. Up to $1,000,000 is allocated for analyses and evaluations each fiscal year. The Director, in consultation with other Federal agencies, conducts periodic analyses and evaluations on effective treatments for methamphetamine abuse. An annual report is submitted to specific Senate and House committees. $40,000,000 is authorized for this purpose. Authorization of appropriations is $40,000,000 for fiscal year 1999, with additional funding as needed for each following year. SEC. 5. EXPANDING METHAMPHETAMINE RESEARCH. Section 464N of the Public Health Service Act is amended to allow grants for interdisciplinary research on methamphetamine abuse and addiction, including studying its effects on the human body and addictive nature.
